>So, if your codeis done then yes it's too late. 
>Then there isn't any unit test approach.


    I don't quite agree there. I not too recently had to work with some legacy code. It was rather buggy and haphazardly tested, I was in a potential minefield, "change something here and break something there" ...kind of situation. 

    Since our QA dept was having a field day with issues ;-), I had no go but to bite the bullet and make changes. I also wrote JUnit tests around what ever functionality I added or modified. Of course I did break some code here and there, what I would do was build tests around those  and then fix them. It was initially a bit hectic not to mention messy at first. I don't want to sound like a commercial but what I have now are quite a bunch of tests in place that really help in detecting in most 'ripple effect' bugs, and yes as a programmer it has really raised my confidence level in the robustness of the code. 

Next on my agenda is trying to structure the tests into a more organized manner and see if I can build tests around the non-tested portions -(ok my pipe dreams...but I hope to realize this soon).

My personal view from experience it's never too late to write those tests ;-), you'll really be glad you did. So while writing tests before coding is highly desirable, it doesn'tmean you're locked out from writing tests for existing code.


Cheers !!

George

 

----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Morten Grum, PH-Consult 
  To: junit@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, February 26, 2003 7:58 PM
  Subject: RE: [junit] Need help!!


  The Unit test approach is "write the test before the code". So, if your code
  is done then yes it's too late. Then there isn't any unit test approach.
  Just stick to use-case tests.

  Morten

  > -----Original Message-----
  > From: Sukhvinder Singh Namdhari [mailto:snamdhari@...]
  > Sent: 26. februar 2004 07:36

  > Subject: [junit] Need help!!

  > Hi,
  >
  > I have query regarding Unit Tests, I want to write unit tests for
  > my Server application, but till now we haven't wrote any testing
  > code, the application is ready and we are doing Smoke tests and
  > regression tests. Anyone could suggest how I could apply unit
  > test technique in the existing Server Application, what should be
  > the approach for Unit tests.
  > Any help would be appreciable.
  >
  > thanks,
  >
  > Jims.
